Award.AwardTitle: Digitization TCN: Collaborative: Documenting the Occurrence through Space & Time of Aquatic Non-indigenous Fish, Mollusks, Algae, & Plants Threatening North America's Great
Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the greatest threats to the health of North America's Great Lakes is invasion by exotic species, several of which already have had catastrophic impacts on property values, the fisheries, shipping, and tourism industries, and continue to threaten the survival of native species and wetland ecosystems. Additional species have been placed on watchlists because of their potential to become aquatic invasives. This project will create a network of herbaria and zoology museums from among the Great Lakes states of MN, WI, IL, IN, MI, OH, and NY to better document the occurrence of these species in space and time by imaging and providing online access to the information on the specimens of the critical organisms. Several initiatives are already in place to alert citizens to the dangers of spreading aquatic invasives among our nation's waterways, but this project will develop complementary scientific and educational tools for scientists, students, wildlife officers, teachers, and the public who have had little access to images or data derived directly from preserved specimens collected over the past three centuries.

This bi-national Thematic Collections Network of >25 institutions from eight states and Canada will digitize 1.73 million historical specimens representing 2,550 species of exotic fish, clams, snails, mussels, algae, plants, and their look-alikes documented to occur in the Great Lakes Basin. It is one of the first efforts to digitize liquid preserved specimens and to integrate cross-kingdom taxa and these methods could become national standards for cross taxon digitization. Students will be provided with hands-on experience in modern methods of specimen curation and this cross-taxon network will provide greater flexibility to existing web platforms for integration of data. This award is made as part of the National Resource for Digitization of Biological Collections through the Advancing Digitization of Biological Collections program and all data resulting from this award will be available through the national resource (iDigBio.org).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The New York Botanical Garden successfully completed its objectives for the National Science Foundation grant titled: Digitization TCN: Collaborative: Documenting the Occurrence through Space & Time of Aquatic Non-indigenous Fish, Mollusks, Algae, & Plants Threatening North America's Great Lakes.  This project was a collaborative digitization grant involving 20 partner institutions across the United States. The project as a whole digitized over one million specimens of invasive species and their relatives from 49 plant genera known from the Great Lakes region. This massive resource of information can be used to track the spread of invasive species in the region and to predict if other related species might become invasive in the future.  


The New York Botanical Garden provided over 165,000 specimen records of the total, including 156,000 specimen images and nearly 60,000 records with geocoordinates.  This number is over 13,000 more than originally estimated. The digitization work on this project was performed by a project coordinator and several student interns.  


In addition to the digitization work, the students participated in the internship program at NYBG, which is geared towards training the next generation of scientists, museum specialists, teachers and stewards of the environment.  They were part of a broader training program in general herbarium protocols from specimen handling and filing to all aspects of specimen digitization, including barcoding, data entry, specimen imaging and georeferencing. Interns attended weekly lectures from the Garden’s science and humanities seminar series and participated in behind the scenes tours and met with professional staff from horticulture, science, economic botany and the library.  


The data created during this project have all been made freely available to researchers and the public through the Great Lakes Invasive Species Network Symbiota portal, the New York Botanical Garden’s Virtual Herbarium, the Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF), Integrated Digitized Biocollections (iDigBio), and others.  


Invasive species wreak havoc on the ecological and economic vitality of this country, especially in the Great Lakes region.  Making data about the distribution of these species and their relatives freely available to researchers, government agencies and the public can help determine where these species have or will have the greatest negative impact and allow for the development of conservation strategies to mitigate these effects.



Last Modified: 06/04/2019
Modified by: Melissa Tulig
